meta.title: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), including HIV-associated nephropathy (HIVAN)

content:
Introduction

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is characterized by scarring (sclerosis) that affects some (focal) glomeruli and only parts (segmental) of the involved glomerular tuft.  It can occur from multiple disease processes, each with a distinct underlying mechanism.  FSGS is classified as primary, secondary, and genetic.  Although FSGS represents a significant cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults, many patients exhibit subnephrotic proteinuria that does not meet criteria for nephrotic syndrome.

Epidemiology



FSGS accounts for approximately 35% of adult nephrotic syndrome cases and is the leading glomerular cause of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) unrelated to systemic diseases.  It is 4 times more common in Black individuals compared to White or Asian patients and affects men 1.5 to 2 times more frequently than women.  FSGS is uncommon in children, in whom minimal change disease (MCD) is the predominant cause of nephrotic syndrome; when present, FSGS is usually genetic.

Pathophysiology and clinical presentation



FSGS is driven by injury to podocytes, the specialized visceral epithelial cells essential for maintaining the glomerular filtration barrier (

figure 1
).  Podocyte injury, characterized by foot process effacement (flattening), disrupts the filtration barrier, leading to significant proteinuria.  Proteinuria, in turn, injures the tubules because excess protein activates cellular stress pathways and causes cytokine release.  This promotes tubulointerstitial fibrosis, a key determinant of progressive kidney dysfunction.



In addition, podocyte loss exposes glomerular capillaries to hemodynamic stress, triggering maladaptive repair processes.  Parietal epithelial cells migrate to injured sites, where they form cellular accumulations that evolve into scar-like segmental sclerosis lesions.  As damage accumulates, fewer functional nephrons remain, forcing surviving nephrons to compensate through increased workload, resulting in glomerular hyperfiltration.  This hyperfiltration further strains podocytes, perpetuating the cycle of injury and progressive kidney damage.

Primary FSGS



Primary FSGS involves podocyte injury caused by a circulating permeability factor believed to be immune mediated.  The soluble urokinase plasminogen activator receptor (suPAR) is the most widely accepted factor.  Clinically, primary FSGS usually presents with nephrotic syndrome (ie, proteinuria >3.5 g/day, hypoalbuminemia, generalized edema).

Secondary FSGS



Secondary FSGS arises from external factors that cause podocyte injury.  The most common mechanism of injury is glomerular hyperfiltration, which is characterized by a maladaptive increase in the glomerular filtration rate per nephron due to an overall reduction in the number of functional glomeruli.  Causes of hyperfiltration injury include:



  • Severe obesity:  An overall rise in blood volume increases pressure within the glomerular capillaries, leading to podocyte shear stress.

  • Reduced nephron mass:  A decrease in the number of total nephrons stresses the remaining nephrons.  This can be seen in patients with reflux nephropathy, sickle cell disease, or low birth weight (reduced kidney mass) and in those with a solitary kidney.



In addition to hyperfiltration injury, direct injury can occur from:



  • Drugs and toxins:  Intravenous heroin use is a classic association thought to cause injury due to adulterants.  Additional causes include interferon therapy, bisphosphonates, and anabolic steroids.

  • Infections:  A number of viral infections have been implicated, HIV being the most common (ie, HIV-associated nephropathy [HIVAN]).  HIVAN represents a severe, rapidly progressive form of FSGS, also known as "collapsing glomerulopathy."  Patients with advanced disease (low CD4+ cell count, high viral load) are most susceptible.



With the exception of HIVAN, secondary FSGS typically presents more insidiously than primary FSGS, usually with subnephrotic proteinuria (1-3 g/day) without nephrotic syndrome; albumin is often normal, and peripheral edema is milder or altogether absent.  This may be due to the slower development of proteinuria in secondary FSGS, which allows for compensatory mechanisms to set in and counter urinary protein loss.

Genetic FSGS



Genetic FSGS results from mutations in podocyte proteins, including nephrin (ŒùŒ°H–Ö1), podocin (NPHS2), and actinin-alpha-4 (ACTN4).  Most cases present in childhood due to autosomal recessive inheritance with full penetrance, and they often progress to severe nephrotic syndrome.  Adult-onset FSGS is usually autosomal dominant with variable penetrance, although the full clinical spectrum in adults remains incompletely characterized.

Diagnosis

Renal biopsy



Renal biopsy is required to establish the diagnosis of FSGS and can help distinguish primary from secondary disease, which is critical for guiding management.  Methods for obtaining general histologic findings in FSGS include:



  • Light microscopy:  Demonstrates focal and segmental areas of sclerosis affecting only some glomeruli (

    image 1
    ).

  • Immunofluorescence:  Usually shows no immune deposits (eg, lack of immunoglobulins, immune complexes, and complement).

  • Electron microscopy:  Typically shows effacement of podocyte foot processes (similar to that of MCD).



Light microscopy findings in primary and secondary FSGS are usually indistinguishable, except for the following unique findings in HIVAN: glomerular capillary wall collapse and sclerosis (often affecting the entire glomerular tuft), glomerular epithelial cell enlargement and proliferation (pseudocrescents), and cystic tubular dilation and filling with proteinaceous material.



Electron microscopy findings are key for distinguishing primary (‚â•80% effacement [diffuse]) from secondary (<80% effacement [segmental]) FSGS.  In addition, lysosomal vacuoles and microvillous degeneration suggest primary FSGS.

Clinical assessment



The presence of nephrotic syndrome (ie, proteinuria >3.5 g/day, hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia) increases the likelihood of primary FSGS, although secondary FSGS can also cause nephrotic syndrome (especially in patients with HIVAN).



Although microscopic hematuria and acute kidney injury (AKI) are more classically seen in nephritic syndrome, they can also be seen in FSGS (50% and 25%-50% of cases, respectively) particularly in primary disease.  This reflects glomerular structural damage with mechanical disruption of glomerular capillaries and reduced nephron function, instead of inflammation-mediated injury; as such, red blood cell casts are not a feature.



A thorough history helps identify secondary FSGS risk factors, including a solitary kidney (ie, reduced nephron mass), drug/toxin exposure, infections (particularly HIV), and a family history (genetic FSGS).



Proteinuria quantification (24-hr urine or spot protein/creatinine ratio) aids diagnosis and monitoring.  In atypical cases, additional tests, including serologic studies for autoimmune diseases (eg, antinuclear antibodies), are warranted.

Management

General principles



General management goals in all forms of FSGS include:



  • Minimizing proteinuria:  This is achieved by blocking the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system using an ACE inhibitor or angiotensin II receptor blocker.

  • Controlling blood pressure:  If further blood pressure reduction is needed, additional medications may be used.  Diuretics are particularly helpful in those with volume overload (eg, significant AKI).

  • Controlling hyperlipidemia:  Hyperlipidemia is common in patients with nephrotic syndrome; dietary measures and statins are commonly used in these patients.



Dietary sodium/protein restriction is also recommended.  Sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 inhibitors are often used for their potential glomerular protective effect.

Primary FSGS



In patients with primary FSGS who have nephrotic syndrome, immunosuppression with glucocorticoids is recommended.  Calcineurin inhibitors (eg, tacrolimus) can be used instead in patients with contraindications to glucocorticoids or in those with glucocorticoid-resistant disease.  Response rates are lower than those in MCD.  In patients without nephrotic syndrome, immunosuppression is typically not used; these patients should be closely monitored for the development of nephrotic syndrome.

Secondary and genetic FSGS



Immunosuppression is not recommended in secondary FSGS, given that it is not an immune-mediated process.  Addressing the underlying cause is key.  For example, weight loss should be recommended in patients with obesity to reduce hyperfiltration injury.  In patients with HIVAN, antiretroviral therapy can slow the progression of renal disease, although ESRD can still develop.



In genetic FSGS, treatment beyond general measures is typically not effective; immunosuppression is sometimes given with questionable benefit, although some case reports show efficacy.

Prognosis



The clinical course of FSGS is variable.  The prognosis depends largely on the initial degree of proteinuria, the level of renal function at diagnosis, and the response to therapy.  Patients who have steroid resistance or significant renal impairment are at increased risk for progression to ESRD.  HIVAN, in particular, carries a poor prognosis.  Early diagnosis and aggressive management of proteinuria and hypertension in all forms of FSGS can slow the progression of kidney damage.  Overall, renal outcomes in FSGS are less favorable compared to the outcomes in MCD.

Summary



Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (

) is a complex and heterogeneous disorder defined by focal and segmental glomerular scarring.  It encompasses multiple etiologies‚Äîincluding primary immune-mediated injury, secondary hyperfiltration or toxic injury, and genetic mutations affecting podocyte integrity‚Äîeach with distinct clinical and histopathologic features.  Epidemiologically, FSGS is more prevalent in adults, particularly among Black individuals and male patients, and its incidence is rising in association with obesity (ie, hyperfiltration injury).  A careful clinical assessment, including detailed history, laboratory evaluation, and renal biopsy, is essential for accurately classifying the disease.  Management centers on the reduction of proteinuria and blood pressure via renin-angiotensin-aldosterone blockade and lifestyle modifications, with immunosuppressive therapy reserved for primary FSGS.  The prognosis is variable and hinges on the underlying etiology, initial disease severity, and response to treatment.
